instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Hi

Unit stopped turning on, no visible liquid or other damage

Getting 5v then goes up to 20v and stays there forever but pulling only 0.01A
checked a few things

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.99v
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>       3.39v

L6995 to ground
Pin 1 277
Pin 2 276 (is it too low?)

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> 20.1v
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 5v
VDDA 12.9v
VDDP 5v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>* 3.3v
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> 3.3v
AMON 0v
BMON 0v


<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v

Any advice appreciated

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Forget <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, if already got 13V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Thanks

Nothing on  <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>

Please advise, I cant seem to work out where <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> originates from

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message: Check <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>'s (7 OF 10) LDO voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Thank you

I hope I checked the right ones

Pin 16 <SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL> 4.9v
Pin 39 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL> 3.2V
Pin 46 <SIGNAL>BANJO_FBLDO1</SIGNAL> 0v
Pin 73 <SIGNAL>BANJO_VINLDO1S</SIGNAL> 0v

The rest is just copies of the LDO5V or LDO3V
You have asked me to check 7 of 10 if I understand correctly so I am obviously missing something.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
(7 OF 10) is the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> block in schematic.

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> comes on?
Check <SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL>.
Also check <CHIP>U7890</CHIP>, pins 2, 4, 6.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Ok, thanks

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL> 3.2V

<CHIP>U7890</CHIP>

Pin2 0v
Pin4 0v
Pin6 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7822</RESISTOR> is good.

<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> is there?

Test starting in SMC bypass mode.
Check for short on all big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> 3v

<RESISTOR>R7822</RESISTOR> no matches found <CAPACITOR>C7822</CAPACITOR> doesnt exist either I hope its a typo

Test starting in SMC bypass mode. - I've tried that with/without battery - doesnt seem to make any difference. I dont have a test chassis thou so maybe keyboard is bad but thats a long shot. Lots of shorts on coils so I am guessing this is something to work out

Checking coils (motherboard disconnected, red on ground, COM on coil terminal)

L7370 short to ground on pin 1(<SIGNAL>SAVR_SW</SIGNAL>) not sure if that's normal
( checked around L7370 - all seems fine, the small cap by the cpu short on both ends C10C5. <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0G</SIGNAL> short to ground everywhere I check)
L7220 short to ground on both terminals (tested caps around the cpu <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground)
L7210 short to ground on both terminals
L7410/20/30 short on both terminals
L7730 no shorts
L7030 - no shorts
L8030 - no shorts
L7960  - no shorts
L8410 no shorts
L7690 - short on both ends
L7670 - no shorts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Sorry, check <RESISTOR>R7862</RESISTOR> instead.

If you associate beep with short, is a big mistake!
Multimeters beep until 0.050-0.075, depending by model.

Please post diode mode to ground readings on the coils.
Switch to ohm scale for values lower than 0.010 in diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7862</RESISTOR> 3.2v on both pins

Yes, it was the beeps that I considered shorts
2k scale

L7900 Pin 1 .046 Pin 2 .046
L8060   Pin 1  .061      Pin 2  .061
L7370   Pin 1  .009      Pin 2  .009
L7220   Pin 1  .006      Pin 2  .006
L7210   Pin 1  .006      Pin 2  .006
L7410   Pin 1  .002      Pin 2  .002
L7420   Pin 1  .002      Pin 2  .003 
L8030   Pin 1  .561      Pin 2  .561
L7960   Pin 1  .065      Pin 2  .066
L7730   Pin 1  .484      Pin 2  .484

L7430   Pin 1  very jumpy to infinity and down to .003        Pin 2  .003  

L7030   this one 20k scale  Pin 1  13.43      Pin 2  13.43

L8410   this one 200M scale  Pin 1 1.1  Pin 2  1.1

L7690   this one 200 scale  Pin 1 0.5   Pin 2 0.5

L7670   this one 20k Pin 1 14.25  Pin 2 14.25

I hope it makes sense

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Not too much sense; did you read my last post?
"post [U]diode mode[/U] to ground readings"

More information here, in case didn't read all thread before.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]
"[U]Test in diode mode:[/U]
   Connect positive probe of the multimeter (red) to ground and touch the test point with black probe.
   Sometime (rarely) we need to test in reverse direction."

BTW, don't waste time checking on both pins of a coil.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
I did just that. All readings are diode mode to ground, red to ground
Some of the coils would show out of range so I had to change the scale
Attached picture of my multimeter

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
L7410/20/30 are tied together.
Any reason to check any of them?
Good enough to check on common (output) pin.
Same applies for L7210/20.
Try to understand a schematic, instead of wasting time.
And stop to check on both pins; do you really expect to get different readings?

You can't get out of range reading in diode mode, when red probe is connectd to ground!
I already said to switch to ohm (not K/M) scale for very low values only.
I'm sure you will understand the reason in time.

However, I don't see any strange value, but should be better to compare with good board.

Remove <CHIP>U7890</CHIP> and join together pads 4 & 6.
Then check for voltage at L7690.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Hi
I simply don't know what I don't know. I've signed up for electronic engineering course as I am getting more and more of such jobs. Thank you for bearing with my pure ignorance.

Removed <CHIP>U7890</CHIP>, joined 4&6

L7690 1.08v
as it was plugged <CAPACITOR>C7933</CAPACITOR> went red hot - removed it, line is not shorted, I have another cap from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, original is X6S and the replacement is X5R, does it matter if other specs match?

Edit: well replaced it and it didnt burn so seems fine, now L7690 has 3.28v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Is important to be 10uF/6.3V.
But you can also use one rated for higher nominal voltage, like10V; just make space for it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Ok, <CAPACITOR>C7933</CAPACITOR> replaced,
With <CHIP>U7890</CHIP> removed and pins 4&6 connected, PP3v3S5 is 3.28v
When I put <CHIP>U7890</CHIP> back, PP3v3S5 is 0.01v
Is it <CHIP>U7890</CHIP> then? or does it mean something else?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
So <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> power supply is good now.
But still not enabled by PMIC.

Keep <CHIP>U7890</CHIP> soldered and check again voltage on its pins 2, 4, 6.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont boot
threads.message:
Ok
Pin 2  0v
Pin 4  0v
Pin 6  3.28v
